[[Gladys Oyenbot]] | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 26{{cite web|title=Catalogue|url=http://www.discopabidjancatalogue.com/|website=Disco Pabidjan Catalogue|accessdate=5 February 2018}} | distributor = CoteQuest Audiovisuel | runtime = 30 minutes |cinematography = |website = | company =Fastrack Productions | camera = [[Multiple-camera setup|Alternative Two Camera]] | picture_format = [[Color]] }} '''''5 @Home''''' sometimes '''5 at Home''' is a Ugandan drama television series starring [[Raymond Rushabiro]], Tumusiime Nicole, Jovan Lugave, Alen Komujuni and Arinaitwe Ramadhan that premiered on [[Fox Life]]{{cite news|title=Local TV series debuts on Fox Life|url=http://kampalasun.co.ug/2017/07/27/local-tv-series-debuts-on-fox-life/|accessdate=5 February 2018|agency=The Kampala Sun}} in July 2017.{{cite web|title=(Uganda) TV Series 5@Home to Premiere in West Africa|url=http://rogmusicafrica.com/2017/07/26/12346/|website=Rog Music Africa}} ==Plot== Henry Muwonge, the patriarch of the modern African Muwonge family loses his government job after national elections and is forced to downgrade his family. It's hard for the family members to get used to living on a limited budget. {{cite news |last1=Anito |first1=Daisy |title=Ugandan TV series debuts on Fox Life |url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/magazine/Ugandan-TV-series-debuts-on-Fox-Life/434746-4027250-r2jcec/index.html |accessdate=11 August 2018 |agency=The East African |date=22 July 2017}}{{cite web |title=Uganda: New TV Series makes it to Fox Life |url=http://afrovibes.us/uganda-new-tv-series-makes-it-to-fox-life/ |website=Afrovibes |accessdate=11 August 2018}} ==Production and release== The series is a production of Fasttrack Productions. It was initially meant for NTV but production was halted for years citing production costs.{{cite news |title=5 At Home Premiers on Fox Life |url=https://www.observer.ug/lifestyle/53352-5-at-home-premieres-on-fox-life.html |accessdate=11 August 2018 |agency=The Observer}} It was first released on YouTube on 14 July 2015 and later picked up by [[Fox Life]]. ==See also== *[[The Life (2012 Film)]] *[[Yat Madit]] *[[Deception NTV]] *[[Balikoowa in the City]] *[[The Hostel]] *[[Beneath The Lies]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{commons}} {{DEFAULTSORT:5 atHome}} [[Category:Ugandan drama television series]] [[Category:Ugandan television series]] [[Category:Television series by network]] [[Category:2015 television series debuts]] {{Africa-tv-stub}}

{{for|the restaurant|Aatxe (restaurant)}}
'''Aatxe''' ({{IPA-eu|a.atʃe|}}) is a spirit in the folk [[Basque mythology|mythology]] of the [[Basque people]]. His name is literally translated as "Young Bull", and he is sometimes known as '''Etsai'''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Spirits, Fairies, Leprechauns and Goblins|publisher=Norton|isbn=0-393-31792-7|chapter=A|year=1998|last=Rose|first=Carol|page=1}}</ref> He is a [[cave]]-dwelling spirit who adopts the form of a young red bull, but being a [[shapeshifter]], sometimes takes the shape of a man.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Element Encyclopedia of Magical Creatures|publisher=Harper Collins|isbn=0-00-720873-1|year=2005|last=Matthews|first=John & Caitlin|page=5}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book |last1=Patxi Xabier Lezama Perier |title=Basque Mythology: History of the myths and deities of the Basque Mythology |date=2018 |location=Euskadi Public Reading Network / Google |url=https://play.google.com/store/books/details/Basque_Mythology_History_of_the_myths_and_deities_?id=vlpZDwAAQBAJ&hl=en_US }}</ref>At night, more so in stormy weather, he arises from the hollow which is his lair. He attacks criminals and other malevolent people. He also protects people by making them stay home when danger is near.
He is theorized to be a representative of the goddess [[Mari (goddess)|Mari]], or may be an enforcer of her will, punishing people who cheat her. Another name for him is Aatxegorri which means "young red bull". It is believed Aatxe inhabited caves and hollows; in many ([[Isturits]], [[Sare]], [[Errenteria]], among others) engravings and paintings depicting aurochs, bulls, and oxen have been found; which implies that this Basque myth has its origins in the Paleolithic.<ref>[http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/5626 Aatxe entry] at the Auñamendi Entziklopedia (in Spanish)</ref>
==In popular culture== Aatxe is used as the name of horned shadow monsters in the [[Guild Wars]] franchise.
On 12 December 2014, Aatxes were added to the popular smartphone game [[Disco Zoo]].
In the upcoming webcomic "Sparrow," one of the main characters, called the Red Horn, is an Aatxe.
In the 1982 film [[The_Last_Unicorn_(film)|The Last Unicorn]], a monster called The Red Bull appears to have many similarities to the Aatxe. Such similarities include dwelling in a cave, and only emerging from his lair at night. He is also described as a ghost by the character Prince Lir.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Basque mythology]] [[Category:Basque legendary creatures]]

{{unreferenced|date=May 2012}} Originally the '''Anglo-Belarusian Society''' (Belarusian: Англа-беларускае таварыства) was a part of the [[Association of Belarusians in Great Britain]]. Because of the growing interest of the British public in Belarus and Belarusians, it was established as a separate organisation on 16 March 1954. The society's object is diffusion, interchange and publication of knowledge relating to the Belarusian people, their land, history and culture.
The first president of the Anglo-Belarusian Society was [[William David Ormsby-Gore]]. A long-serving President of the Society was Frances Ward (Lady Phipps), wife of [[Eric Phipps]]. Another woman who was actively involved in Anglo-Belarusian Society was [[Katharine Macmillan]], a vice-chairman of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] in 1968. She served first as the organisation's Vice President and then President.
Despite its "Anglo-" label, the society was not intended to exclude Scotland, Wales and other parts of the UK. Among the early cultural activities of the society was the publication of a regular pamphlet on Belarus and the organisation of concerts of Belarusian church chants, folk songs and dances in [[Westminster Cathedral]] Hall in 1950s.
Since 1965 the society has been publishing the ''[[Journal of Belarusian Studies]]''.
== External links == * [http://absociety.org.uk Anglo-Belarusian Society web site] * [http://belarusjournal.com Journal of Belarusian Studies]

{{Infobox building | name = Arch 22 | native_name= | image = Gambia banjul arch22.JPG | caption = Arch 22 serves as a distinctive gateway to the Gambian capital. | former_names = | alternate_names = | building_type = City gate | architectural_style = [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] | structural_system = | cost = | location = [[Banjul]],[[the Gambia]] | map_type = Gambia | pushpin_label =Arch 22 | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | coordinates = {{coord|13.460|N|16.582|W|display=inline,title|source:dewiki}} | altitude = | start_date = 1996 | completion_date = | inauguration_date = | demolition_date = | height = | diameter = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | main_contractor = | architect = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | references = }} [[File:Gambia, Banjul, Arch 22.jpg|thumb|Arch 22 in Banjul, Gambia, photographed with a drone.]] [[Image:Banjuljuly22.JPG|thumb|]] [[Image:Banjuljuly22b.JPG|thumb|Statue of the "unknown soldier" stands close to the base of the Arch.]] '''Arch 22''' is a commemorative arch on the road into [[Banjul]] in [[the Gambia]]. It was built in 1996 to mark the military [[1994 Gambian coup d'état|coup d'état]] of July 22, 1994, through which [[Yahya Jammeh]] and his [[Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council]] overthrew the democratically elected Gambian government.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Ham | first1 = Anthony | title = West Africa | publisher = Lonely Planet | year = 2009 | location = London | pages = 295 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1HapewBo3c0C&lpg=PA295&ots=pHm1011pNk&dq=%22pierre%20goudiaby%22%20arch%2022&pg=PA295#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate = 2011-06-07}}</ref>
The Arch stands on the Banjul-[[Serrekunda]] Highway, near the traffic island at the intersection with Box Bar Road, Independence Drive, and Marina Parade. A statue of the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier|"unknown soldier"]] can be seen near the base of the arch: the soldier has a rifle strapped to his back and carries a baby in one hand while signaling [[victory]] (making a [[V-sign]]) with the other.
Arch 22 is depicted on the back of the 100-[[Gambian dalasi|dalasis]] banknote.
== Construction == The Arch was designed by Senegalese architect [[Pierre Goudiaby]], who also designed the [[Yundum International Airport]] at Banjul and the [[African Renaissance Monument]] in Dakar, Senegal.
At 35 metres, the Arch is one of the tallest structures in the Gambia. The building stands on eight columns and has three floors. Access to the upper floors can be made through several elevators and spiral cases.
The first floor is at an intermediate level in the columns. The gallery on the second floor provides an impressive panorama of the city, with the view extending down to the sea port of Banjul and the mangrove forests of [[Tanbi Wetland Complex]]. On the top floor is a small textile museum.
Because the stability of the construction is in doubt, the Arch has been closed to traffic.
== References == {{Portal|The Gambia}} {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox Recurring event |image = Apic logo.jpg |imagesize = 150 px |caption = |begins = |ends = |date = |frequency = Annual |location = [[India]], [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], [[Taiwan]], [[Thailand]], [[Pakistan]] |first = |last = |participants = |footnotes = }} The '''Asia Petrochemical Industry Conference''' ('''APIC''') is an annual, international [[Meeting|conference]] within the [[petrochemical industry]] intended to "spur mutual friendship and goodwill" within the industry with an aim to encouraging its "sound development".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.apic-online.org/about_apic.html | title = About APIC | accessdate = 2009-11-03}}</ref> Known at its 1979 founding as the East Asia Petrochemical Industry Conference, it was a combined project of industry associations within [[Japan]], [[Korea]] and [[Taiwan]],<ref>{{cite book | title = Asia Yearbook 1980 | publisher = International Publications Service | year = 1980 | isbn = 962-7010-06-5 | page = 126}}</ref> which northern Asian nations alternated hosting duties. In 2000, the conference was retitled to its current name when [[India]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Singapore]] entered the hosting rotation. [[Thailand]] is also currently among the conference's hosts. The 2009 conference hosted in [[Seoul]] was attended by over 850 officials from 28 countries.<ref>{{cite news | title = Oil products conference to be held in Seoul | work = Korean Herald | author = Lee Yong-sung | date = 2009-05-14 }}</ref> The 2010 conference was held on 13 and 14 May in [[Mumbai]] and attended by over 1400 delegates from 40 countries.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://cpmaindia.com/index.php/ |title= Chemical and Petrochemical Manufacturers' Association, India (CPMA) | accessdate = 2009-11-03}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091125184851/http://www.apic-online.org/ Official site]
[[Category:International conferences]] [[Category:Petrochemical industry]]

revision.text:
'''Coffee Strong''' is a GI coffeehouse based on the tradition of resistance coffee houses opened during the [[Vietnam war]] by antiwar veterans and active duty soldiers. Based in [[Lakewood, WA]] it was founded in 2008 by veterans returning from the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|wars in Afghanistan]] and [[Iraq War|Iraq]]. It is located within 300 meters of the gates at [[Joint Base Lewis-McChord]]. It is one of three currently active GI resistance coffee houses along with [[Under the Hood Café]] near [[Fort Hood]] in Texas & [[Norfolk Offbase]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia]]. According to Coffee Strong board member Zoltan Grossmanhttp://www.counterpunch.org/grossman03102009.html
The goal of the G.I. coffeehouse is to provide soldiers, their families and recent vets a place away from the base where they can learn about resources available to them, meet with G.I. rights counselors, and access alternative information. It holds weekly movie nights, and hosts speakers, hiphop, punk and folk concerts, and other events. The response from soldiers visiting the coffeehouse has so far been overwhelmingly positive.
The Coffee Strong advisory board includes linguist and dissident [[Noam Chomsky]], [[Marjorie Cohn]], [[Mike Ferner]], [[Eva Golinger]], [[Dahr Jamail]], [[Antonia Juhasz]], [[Ann Wright|Col. Ann Wright (Ret.)]], and the late historian and author [[Howard Zinn]].http://www.coffeestrong.org/about/ In 2011 filmmaker and professor of Folklore and English at the University of Oregon [[Lisa Gilman]] released the film ''[[Grounds for Resistance]]''http://groundsforresistance.com/http://www.thenewstribune.com/2011/05/13/1663377/find-common-ground-at-gi-coffee.html about Coffee Strong and featured interviews by some of its founders and reactions to it from Joint Base Lewis-McChord soldiers. ==See also== * [[Under the Hood Café]] * [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]] * [[The Shelter Half]] * [[GI Coffeehouses]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.coffeestrong.org/}} *[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/coffeecity/2011924594_the_comic_strip_betty_took.html Seattle Times : Weekend Wrap] *[http://groundsforresistance.com/2011/03/22/hello-world/ Official website for the documentary film Grounds for Resistance by Lisa Gilman.] *[http://www.alternet.org/world/130262/how_one_coffee_shop_in_washington_state_is_providing_a_haven_for_war_resisters Alternet : How One Coffee Shop in Washington State is Providing a Haven For War Resisters] *[http://www.counterpunch.org/grossman03102009.html/ Coffee Strong: Listening to the G.I. Voice at Fort Lewis, by Zoltan Grossman.] *[http://www.armytimes.com/news/2010/03/offduty_coffeehouses_030110w/ New era for coffeehouses rooted in anti-war tradition, in Army Times (3/7/10).] {{coord|47.1214|-122.5540|type:landmark_region:US-WA|display=title}} [[Category:Anti–Iraq War groups]] [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:History of Tacoma, Washington]] [[Category:Coffee houses of the United States]]

{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Austria.svg|150 px]]}} '''Austria''' has a well-developed institutional and [[legal system]], and most '''[[corruption]]''' cases under investigation by a [[parliamentary committee]] end with [[judicial]] trials and effective judgments. However, there are several significant [[Austria]]n corruption cases which have taken place during the past decade involving land and [[regional]] officials, high-level public officials, the central government and, in one instance, the former [[Chancellor]].<ref name="business-anti-corruption1">{{cite web|title=Austria Corruption Profile-Political Climate|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/austria/show-all.aspx|publisher=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref>
In most cases, corrupt practices were related to conflicts of interest, [[abuse]] of office, money [[Money laundering|laundering]] and influence peddling. The corruption [[scandals]] have put into doubt the ethical standards of the political elite.<ref name="business-anti-corruption1"/> This doubt is reflected in the findings of [[Eurobarometer]] 2012, where two-thirds of respondents perceive national [[politicians]] to be corrupt and also the most corrupt institution in Austria.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eurobarometer 2012- Austria|url=http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_374_en.pdf|publisher=The European Commission|accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref>
Transparency International's 2017 Corruption Perception Index ranks the country 16th place out of 180 <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2017|title=Corruption Perceptions Index 2017|last=e.V.|first=Transparency International|date=|work=www.transparency.org|access-date=2017-03-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Extent== According to several sources, corruption is not considered a problem for doing business in Austria. According to [https://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2013/204595.htm Investment Climate Report 2013] by the US Department of State 2013, corruption is not considered as a serious problem impeding business in Austria. The World Economic Forum’s [http://www.weforum.org/ [[Global Competitiveness Report]] 2013-2014] notes that it is uncommon for companies to make irregular payments or bribes connected with imports and exports, public utilities, annual tax payments, and awarding of public contracts and [[licenses]]. Moreover, corruption is ranked as the twelfth most [[problematic]] factor for doing business in Austria.<ref name="business-anti-corruption1"/>
According to the Global Competitiveness Report 2013-2014, [[In-group favoritism|favouritism]] among government officials towards well-connected companies and individuals is a competitive disadvantage for the country. According to [http://www.transparency.de/fileadmin/pdfs/Themen/Vergabe/Identifying_and_Reducing_Corruption_in_Public_Procurement.pdf Identifying and Reducing Corruption in Public Procurement in the EU 2013], officials involved in public procurement lack effective corruption screening.<ref name="business-anti-corruption1"/>
== See also == * [[Crime in Austria]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/austria/snapshot.aspx Austria Corruption Profile] from the [[Business-Anti-Corruption Portal|Business Anti-Corruption Portal]]

revision.text:
'''Dmitri Valeriyevich Pavlichenko''' ({{lang-be|Дзьмітры Валер'евіч Паўлічэнка}}, {{lang-ru|Дмитрий Валерьевич Павличенко}}; alternative spellings: ''Dmitry, Dzmitry, Dzmitri, Vasilyevich, Pavliuchenko, Pawliuchenka'', born 1966 in [[Vitebsk]]) is head of the [[Belarus]]ian Special Rapid Reaction Unit ([[SOBR]]).
==Allegations of assassinations==
In February 2004, [[Christos Pourgourides]] of the [[Council of Europe]]'s [[Committee on Legal Affairs and Human Rights]] reported concerns suggesting that Dmitri Pavlichenko, along with other "senior officials of the State" had been involved in the assassination of several people, including senior politicians.<ref name="COE_pavlichenko">{{cite web| last =Pourgourides| first =Christos| authorlink =| author2 =Committee on Legal Affairs| author3 =Human Rights| author4 =[[Council of Europe]]| title =Disappeared persons in Belarus| work =| publisher =[[Council of Europe]]| date =February 2004| url =http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=/Documents/WorkingDocs/Doc04/EDOC10062.htm| format =| doi =| accessdate =2007-09-18| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090221075513/http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FWorkingDocs%2FDoc04%2FEDOC10062.htm| archivedate =2009-02-21| df =}}</ref>
He stated that the Chief of the Criminal Police of Belarus, General Lapatik, in a handwritten note on November 21, 2000, accused Dmitri Pavlichenko of assassinating [[Jury Zacharanka]], a former Minister of the Interior who [[forced disappearance|disappeared]] on May 7, 1999, with a [[PB pistol]], normally used for carrying out the [[capital punishment in Belarus|death penalty]] at [[Minsk Detention Center No. 1|SIZO-1 prison]], officially signed out from SIZO-1 on the orders of the Minister of the Interior, Sivakov. He also stated suspicions that Pavlichenko was involved in the [[forced disappearance|disappearances]] of [[Victor Gonchar]], Vice-President of the [[Parliament of Belarus]] and businessman Anatoly Krasovski on September 16, 1999.
Pavlichenko was arrested on November 22, 2000. According to Pourgourides' report, the warrant stated (translation) {{quote|The materials of the operational investigation contain trustworthy data confirming that Dmitry Vasiliyevich Pavlichenko is the organiser and head of a criminal body engaged in abduction and physical elimination of people. In particular, the criminal group headed by D.V. Pavlichenko was involved in assassinating G. V. Samoylov, the leader of the RNE, Belarusian unregistered regional organisation, as well as in murdering other individuals. Taking into consideration the fact that D.V. Pavlichenko and his criminal group may commit further crimes of particular violence, [...], decided [to apply a preventive detention for 30 days].|Chief of the [[State Security Agency of the Republic of Belarus|Belarusian KGB]], [[Vladimir Matskevich]]|<ref name="COE_pavlichenko" />}}
While the warrant stated that the detention would be for 30 days, Pavlichenko was released a few days later, either on November 23 (according to Prosecutor General [[Viktor Sheyman]], who became Prosecutor General on November 27) or on November 27 (according to Colonel [[Oleg Alkayev]], head of SIZO-1 at the time, who later was accepted for political [[Asylum in Germany|asylum in]] [[Germany]]). Pourgourides states that the Zakharenko family's lawyer, Volchek, stated that President [[Alexander Lukashenko]] had personally ordered Pavlichenko's release from prison. He also states that the Minister of Agriculture, Leonov, had personally told him that Lukashenko had "violently criticised the KGB for arresting Pavlichenko" on television.
The Governing Council of the [[Inter-Parliamentary Union]] has expressed its concern about these allegations<ref name="ipu_pavlichenko">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title =CASE No BLS/05 - VICTOR GONCHAR: Resolution adopted by the Governing Council at its 176th session (Manila, 8th April 2005)| work =| publisher =[[Inter-Parliamentary Union]]| date = 2005-04-08| url =http://www.ipu.org/hr-e/176/Bls05.htm |format =| doi =| accessdate =2007-09-17 }}</ref> and Pavlichenko is now subject to international financial sanctions among with several other Belarusian senior officials and politicians.<ref name="bank_eng_pavlichenko">{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Consolidated List of Financial Sanctions Targets in the UK |work= |publisher=[[Bank of England]] |date=2006-10-25 |url=http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/publications/financialsanctions/regimes/belarus.htm |format= |doi= |accessdate=2007-09-17 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070712232609/http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/publications/financialsanctions/regimes/belarus.htm |archivedate=2007-07-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>

There have been several seasons of '''drought in [[Afghanistan]]''' in recent decades. According to an analysis of climate and drought records [[Asia Development Bank]], localized droughts have a periodicity of three to five years, and droughts covering large areas recur every 9-11 years.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} South and central areas are more affected from July through September.
Afghanistan began experiencing unusual droughts beginning in 1995, right after the [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan|Taliban]] emerged. It remained this way until heavy snow began falling in the 2002-2003 winter season, after the new [[Presidency of Hamid Karzai|Karzai administration]] took over. This relief did not last long as the country began to see more droughts in the coming years.<ref>[http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/world/afghanistan-drought-will-become-disaster-without-aid-oxfam-says-61832.html Afghanistan Drought Will Become Disaster Without Aid, Oxfam Says] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105182147/http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/world/afghanistan-drought-will-become-disaster-without-aid-oxfam-says-61832.html |date=January 5, 2012 }} by Jack Phillips for [[Epoch Times]]. September 20, 2011</ref>
Drought combined with conflict has created internally displaced populations that are living in extremely poor conditions. Many communities continue to depend on meager incomes derived by migrating outside their farmlands.<ref name="upi">[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/10/06/Severe-drought-hits-Afghanistan/UPI-18541317904385/ Severe drought hits Afghanistan]. October 6, 2011</ref> Inadequate rains and snowfall during 2008 to 2010 in parts of Afghanistan caused significant failure of the rain-fed crops in the country's six provinces: [[Herat Province|Herat]], [[Jawzjan Province|Jawzjan]], [[Balkh Province|Balkh]], [[Badghis Province|Badghis]], [[Faryab Province|Faryab]] and [[Sar-e-Pul Province|Sar-e-Pul]]. The situation affected the most vulnerable populations and their access to food and water, reducing communities' health and nutrition status.<ref name="upi"/> However, in 2012 Afghanistan's long drought has ended due to heavy snow.<ref>ABC News Australia, [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-03-10/death-toll-from-afghan-avalanches-rises-to-56/3881862 145 'presumed dead' in Afghan avalanche]</ref>
